Question:
Given below are four jumbled sentences. Pick the option that gives their correct order.
A. These tribes believe that they can communicate with dead ancestors only through this language.
B. Today, linguists call such a language an “isolated” language.
C. Zuni is a language spoken only by the Zuni tribes.
D. It is remarkable that these tribes have been able to preserve their language.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2.
First is C as it introduces the subject i.e Zuni.
Next is A as it further explains what the tribes believe.
After that is D as it describes how these tribes have preserved the language.
Last is B as it highlights the present scenario.
The correct sequence is -CADB.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the narration (direct / indirect) of the given sentence.
Mary said, “I have to be there by 10 am tomorrow.”
OP1: Mary is telling me that she has to be there by 10 am tomorrow
OP2: Mary says to me that she has to be there by 10 am.
OP3: Mary told me that she had to be there by 10 am the next day.
OP4: Mary tells me she has to be there by 10 am tomorrow.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3.
The speaker is informing something i.e told will be used.
Tomorrow will be changed to the next day in indirect speech.
The first person pronoun will be changed to the third person i.e. she.
Also, the past participle form of the verb will be used.
So option 3 is correct.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the voice (active / passive) form of the given sentence.
I am writing a story after a long time.
OP1: A story is being written by me after a long time.
OP2: I have written a story after a long time.
OP3: A story after a long time was written by me.
OP4: A story had been written by me after a long time.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 1.
In the passive voice, the subject and the object get interchanged. The subject will become a story.
The sentence is in the present continuous tense.
So, the passive voice will be of the form passive subject+is/are being+past participle form of verb+passive object.
So, option 1 is correct.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the narration (direct / indirect) of the given sentence.
Sumit said, “I will be leaving for London this summer so I can meet you only when I return.”
OP1: Sumit said that he would be leaving for London that summer and he could meet me only when he returned.
OP2: Sumit said he will go to London this summer and he would meet me only when he will be returning.
OP3: Sumit said he will be leaving for London this summer and he could meet him only when he returned.
OP4: Sumit said he will have gone to London that summer and could meet me only when he returned.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 1.
In the indirect form, will changes to would and can changes to could.
Also, the first person changes to the third person.
So, I will change to he and you will change to me.
Also, the base form of the verb will be changed to past participle form i.e returned. So, option 1 is correct.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the narration (direct / indirect) of the given sentence.
“You should lock your car as there have been some instances of theft,” said Anil.
OP1: There have been some instances of theft so I should have locked my car said Anil.
OP2: Anil advised me that I should lock my car as there had been some instances of theft.
OP3: There have been instances of theft so I should lock my car was told to me by Anil.
OP4: Anil said he must lock his car because there were some instances of theft.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2.
The word should indicates that Anil is advising.
Have changes to had in the indirect form.
The indirect form must not change the meaning of the sentence. So, clearly option 2 is correct.

Question:
Identify the segment in the sentence, which contains the grammatical error.
I had a hard time paying the driver as I had only hundreds rupee note.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3.
The word hundreds is incorrect as the value of the rupee note is always mentioned as singular.
So, hundred should be used instead of hundreds.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the voice (active/passive) form of the given sentence.
By how many people were you helped in your time of difficulty?
OP1: How many people helped you in your time of difficulty?
OP2: In your time of difficulty how many people were you helped by?
OP3: How many people were you helping in time of difficulty?
OP4: How many people are you helped by in your time of difficulty?
Solution:
The correct answer is option 1.
The given sentence is in the passive voice and the word helped indicates that the active form will be in the simple past tense and is simply asking the number of people.
Option 3 changes the meaning of the sentence.
Option 4 is in the present tense.
option 1 is correct.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the narration (direct / indirect) of the given sentence.
The teacher said to Rana, “Have you completed the project?”
OP1: The teacher asked Rana that if Rana has completed the project.
OP2: The teacher asks Rana will you complete the project.
OP3: The teacher asked Rana whether he had completed the project
OP4: The teacher asks Rana have you completed the project.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3.
The teacher is clearly asking a question so the indirect speech will contain asked. Have changes to had in indirect form. So, option 3 is correct.

Question:
Identify the best way to improve the underlined part of the given sentence. If there is no improvement required, select ‘no improvement’.
You have been so unwell! How you feeling now?
Solution:
The correct answer is option 1.
The auxiliary verb are comes before the pronoun in a sentence. The sentence is missing the word are. Is-- is used with he and she whereas are is used with you. So, option 1 is correct.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the narration (direct / indirect) of the given sentence.
The priest said to me, “You have committed a cardinal sin.”
OP1: The priest told me I am committing a cardinal sin.
OP2: The priest told me that I had committed a cardinal sin.
OP3: The priest is saying I have committed a cardinal sin.
OP4: The priest said if I will be committing a cardinal sin.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2.
The statement clearly indicates that the priest is informing something. So told will be used.
The sentence is in the present perfect tense. So, the indirect form will be in the past perfect tense and will contain had committed. So, option 2 is correct.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the narration (direct / indirect) of the given sentence.
The airline official said, “We are extremely sorry that the flight has been delayed due to heavy floods.”
OP1: The airline official announces they are extremely sorry that the flight has been delayed due to heavy floods.
OP2: The airline official announced that we are extremely sorry that the flight has been delayed due to heavy floods.
OP3: The airline official announced the airline is extremely sorry that the flight will be delayed due to heavy floods.
OP4: The airline official announced that they were extremely sorry that the flight had been delayed due to heavy floods.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4.
The first part of the sentence containing are extremely is in the simple present tense so it will be changed to past tense i.e were extremely.
The second part containing has been will be changed to had been. So, the correct answer is option 4.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the narration (direct / indirect) of the given sentence.
“I’m so sorry! I totally forgot about the meeting,” he said.
OP1: He was so sorry that he had forgot totally about the meeting.
OP2: He is being sorry for having totally forgotten about the meeting.
OP3: He apologized and said that he had totally forgotten about the meeting.
OP4: Having forgotten totally about the meeting he is very sorry.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3.
The speaker is clearly apologizing as observed from the words I'm so sorry. Also, the past participle form of the verb i.e forgotten will be used. The sentence is in the past tense so we will use had in the indirect form.
So, option 3 is correct.

Question:
Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank.
The business prospect seemed quite ______ so I convinced my friend to partner with me to start the venture.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 1.
Lucrative means producing a great deal of profit.
Dubious means hesitating or doubting.
Flourishing means developing rapidly and successfully; thriving.
The speaker is talking about a business prospect so the most appropriate word to be used is lucrative as the speaker was convinced with the prospect.

Question:
Select the most appropriate idiom ( in the context) to fill in the sentence.
In my parents’ time, we mostly ate at home and family outings happened ______
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4.
In fine feather means in excellent form, health, or humour
Shoulder to shoulder means work together.
Behind the back means done without someone knowing about it.
Once in a blue moon means to do very rarely.
The speaker wants to convey that family outings occurred rarely. So, option 4 is correct.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the voice (active / passive) form of the given sentence.
Do you think that the government will accept our demands?
OP1: Do you think that the government is going to accept our demands?
OP2: Do you think we will accept the government demands?
OP3: Do you think that our demands have been accepted by the government?
OP4: Do you think that our demands will be accepted by the government?
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4.
In the passive form, the subject and the object get interchanged.
So, the subject will become our demands.
The passive form will be passive subject +will be + past participle form of verb+ passive object.
So, option 4 is correct.

Question:
Identify the best way to improve the underlined part of the given sentence. If there is no improvement required, select ‘no improvement’.
Please switch on all the lights in the room as it’s getting very dark now.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4.
The sentence uses now which means it is talking about the present situation so we will use the present continuous form.
Option 1 is incorrect grammatically
options 2 and 3 are using past continuous tense.
So, option 4 is correct. as the sentence is grammatically correct.

Question:
Given below are four jumbled sentences. Pick the option that gives their correct order.
A. Furthermore, make sure that you give some vivid details of the city making it as real as you can.
B. For example, if it begins in a city, give details about the city.
C. First of all make it as specific as possible.
D. While writing a story or a novel the setting is very important.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2.
First is D introduces the topic of writing a novel or a story
Then C explains how to go about it
The third is B which gives an example of a point to be included
Lastly comes A explains the specifics needed in it.
The correct sequence is DCBA. Option 2 is the right answer.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the narration (direct / indirect) of the given sentence.
My boss said, “Do you think you can complete the report within five days?”
OP1: My boss asked me whether I thought I could complete the report within five days.
OP2: My boss says do you think you can complete the report within five days.
OP3: My boss said to me if I think I can complete the report within five days.
OP4: My boss said to me do you think I can complete the report within five days?
Solution:
The correct answer is option 1.
The boss is clearly asking a question so asked will be used.
Indirect speech contains the past participle form of the verb.
So, think changes to thought and can changes to could. So, option 1 is correct.

Question:
Identify the best way to improve the underlined part of the given sentence. If there is no improvement required, select ‘no improvement’.
Ravi can’t come to the meeting as he was not well.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3.
The sentence is in the past tense as observed from the word was.
So, we will use the past tense form of can't i.e couldn't.
With couldn't we use the base form of the verb i.e come. So, option 3 is correct.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the narration (direct / indirect) of the given sentence.
The lawyer says, “My client is innocent.”
OP1: The lawyer says my client was innocent.
OP2: The lawyer said that his client is innocent.
OP3: The lawyer says that his client is innocent.
OP4: The lawyer said that my client is innocent.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3.
In indirect speech, my will be changed to his.
So, options 1 and 4 are incorrect.
If in the direct speech you find say/says or will say we do not change tense of reported speech in Indirect Speech sentence so we will use says in indirect speech.
So, option 3 is correct.

Question:
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow.
The four-year tiger census report, Status of Tigers in India, 2018, released by Prime Minister Narendra Modi shows numbers of the cat have increased across all landscapes.
The Global Tiger Forum, an international collaboration of tiger-bearing countries, has set a goal of doubling the count of wild tigers by 2022. More than 80% of the world’s wild tigers are in India, and it’s crucial to keep track of their numbers.
The total count in 2018 has risen to 2,967 from 2,226 in 2014 — an increase of 741 individuals an increase of 33%, in four years.
This is by far the biggest increase in terms of both numbers and percentage since the four yearly census using camera traps and the capture-mark-recapture method began in 2006. The 2018 figure has a great degree of credibility because, according to the report, as many as 2,461 individual tigers (83% of the total) have actually been photographed by trap cameras. In 2014, only 1,540 individuals (69%) were photographed.
The tiger census is needed because the tiger sits at the peak of the food chain, and its conservation is important to ensure the well-being of the forest ecosystem. The tiger estimation exercise includes habitat assessment and prey estimation. The numbers reflect the success or failure of conservation efforts. This is an especially important indicator in a fast growing economy like India where the pressures of development often run counter to the demands of conservation.
Where has the tiger population increased the most?
The biggest increase has been in Madhya Pradesh — a massive 218 individuals (71%) from 308 in 2014 to 526.
However, since tigers keep moving between states, conservationists prefer to talk about tiger numbers in terms of landscapes.
So, why have the numbers gone up?
The success owes a lot to increased vigilance and conservation efforts by the Forest Department. From 28 in 2006, the number of tiger reserves went up to 50 in 2018, extending protection to larger numbers of tigers over the years. Healthy increases in core area populations eventually lead to migrations to areas outside the core; this is why the 2018 census has found tigers in newer areas. Over the years, there has been increased focus on tigers even in the areas under the territorial and commercial forestry arms of Forest Departments.
The other important reason is increased vigilance, and the fact that organized poaching rackets have been all but crushed. According to Nitin Desai of Wildlife Protection Society of India, there has been no organized poaching by traditional gangs in Central Indian landscapes since 2013. The increased protection has encouraged the tiger to breed. Tigers are fast breeders when conditions are conducive.
The rehabilitation of villages outside core areas in many parts of the country has led to the availability of more inviolate space for tigers. Also, because estimation exercises have become increasingly more accurate over the years, it is possible that many tigers that eluded enumerators in earlier exercises were counted this time.

Question:
The Global Tiger Forum comprises -
OP2: all countries of the United Nations.
OP4: National Geographic and World Wildlife Fund.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3.
It is mentioned that ''The Global Tiger Forum, an international collaboration of tiger-bearing countries .'' The word bearing suggests the countries which have tigers.

The total count in 2018 has risen to 2,967 from 2,226 in 2014 — an increase of 741 individuals an increase of 33%, in four years.
This is by far the biggest increase in terms of both numbers and percentage since the four yearly census using camera traps and the capture-mark-recapture method began in 2006. The 2018 figure has a great degree of credibility because, according to the report, as many as 2,461 individual tigers (83% of the total) have actually been photographed by trap cameras. In 2014, only 1,540 individuals (69%) were photographed.
The tiger census is needed because the tiger sits at the peak of the food chain, and its conservation is important to ensure the well-being of the forest ecosystem. The tiger estimation exercise includes habitat assessment and prey estimation. The numbers reflect the success or failure of conservation efforts. This is an especially important indicator in a fast growing economy like India where the pressures of development often run counter to the demands of conservation.
Where has the tiger population increased the most?
The biggest increase has been in Madhya Pradesh — a massive 218 individuals (71%) from 308 in 2014 to 526.
However, since tigers keep moving between states, conservationists prefer to talk about tiger numbers in terms of landscapes.
So, why have the numbers gone up?
The success owes a lot to increased vigilance and conservation efforts by the Forest Department. From 28 in 2006, the number of tiger reserves went up to 50 in 2018, extending protection to larger numbers of tigers over the years. Healthy increases in core area populations eventually lead to migrations to areas outside the core; this is why the 2018 census has found tigers in newer areas. Over the years, there has been increased focus on tigers even in the areas under the territorial and commercial forestry arms of Forest Departments.
The other important reason is increased vigilance, and the fact that organized poaching rackets have been all but crushed. According to Nitin Desai of Wildlife Protection Society of India, there has been no organized poaching by traditional gangs in Central Indian landscapes since 2013. The increased protection has encouraged the tiger to breed. Tigers are fast breeders when conditions are conducive.
The rehabilitation of villages outside core areas in many parts of the country has led to the availability of more inviolate space for tigers. Also, because estimation exercises have become increasingly more accurate over the years, it is possible that many tigers that eluded enumerators in earlier exercises were counted this time.

Question:
What is the tiger population of Madhya Pradesh?
Solution:
The correct answer is option 1.
It is mentioned that ''The biggest increase has been in Madhya Pradesh — a massive 218 individuals (71%) from 308 in 2014 to 526.'' So, option 1 is correct.

Question:

Question:

Question:

Solution:
The correct answer is option 4.
We use the superlative form of adjective when something is considered the highest quality among a group of similar things.

Fine is the base form of the adjective and finer is used while making comparisons.
Option 1 is also incorrect if seen as a part of the complete sentence; for it does not make sense as -- one of the few human beings I have ever met-- is incomplete in its context.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the voice (active / passive) form of the given sentence.
Somebody feeds the stray dog daily.
OP1: Daily somebody has fed the stray dog.
OP2: The stray dog is fed daily by somebody
OP3: The stray dog will be fed daily.
OP4: The stray dog was fed daily.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2.
In the passive voice, the subject and the object get interchanged.
The stray dog will become the subject.
The given sentence is in the simple present tense, so the passive voice will be of the form passive subject+is/are+ past participle form of verb+passive object.
So, option 2 is correct.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the voice (active / passive) form of the given sentence.
High interest rates are alarming automobile dealers.
OP1: Automobile dealers is being alarmed by high interest rates.
OP2: High interest rates have alarmed automobile dealers.
OP3: High interest rates has been alarmed by automobile dealers.
OP4: Automobile dealers are being alarmed by high interest rates.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4)
Explanation:
We need to follow these instructions while changing the voice of an assertive sentence.
  • Identify the subject and object of the given sentence and interchange their places.
    • 'Automobile dealers' which is an object in the active voice becomes the subject in the passive voice and 'High-interest dealers' which is a subject in an active voice becomes the object in the passive voice.
  • Use the preposition ‘by’ before the agent.
  • 'is/are + V4' in active voice changes to 'is/are + being + V3' in passive voice.
Following these steps, we finally get- "Automobile dealers are being alarmed by high-interest rates."

Serenity means the state of being calm, peaceful, and untroubled.

Last is D as it gives information about what the doctors advise in the matter
So, the correct sequence is BACD.

Identify the best way to improve the underlined part of the given sentence. If there is no improvement required, select ‘no improvement’.
My daughter fell asleep while she been reading.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4.
The sentence is in the simple past tense as a past tense form of verb i.e fell is used.
So, we will use the past tense form of been i.e. was. So, option 4 is correct.

Question:
Identify the segment in the sentence, which contains the grammatical error.
I use to going for morning walks when I lived in Dehradun.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4.
We have to use 'I used to go' to signify that the action used to take place regularly at a time in the past, which is what the context of the sentence refers to.

Question:
Select the word which means the same as the group of words given.
A strong feeling of dislike towards someone or something.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3.
Telepathy means the supposed communication of thoughts or ideas by means other than the known senses.
Sympathy means feelings of pity and sorrow for someone else's misfortune.
Antipathy means a strong feeling of dislike towards someone or something.
Empathy means the ability to understand and share the feelings of another.

Question:
Identify the segment in the sentence, which contains the grammatical error.
Instead of studying in home I went to my friend’s house.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4.
The use of the preposition in is incorrect. In is used when something is surrounded by the other.
At is used when referring to something at a particular place, time, day etc.
Here, the use of at is appropriate.

Question:
Given below are four jumbled sentences. Pick the option that gives their correct order.
A Therefore an advanced ambulance needs to reach the patient immediately.
B A cardiac arrest, as is well known, needs revival within 4 minutes.
C A question often asked by us in India is whether we will get timely health care in an emergency.
D But even in Delhi, the capital city, a patient does not get emergency care.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4.
First is C as it gives the introduction of the subject being talked about i.e timely health care.
Next is B as it highlights the topic of cardiac arrest.
After that is A as it describes what should happen after a cardiac arrest.
Last is D as it talks about the status in the capital city
So, the correct sequence is CBAD.

Question:
Given below are four jumbled sentences. Pick the option that gives their correct order.
A His death was a cause of great speculation.
B Edgar Allan Poe was a famous American author.
C Within a few days of being found, he died mysteriously on Oct 7, 1849.
D He had gone missing on October 3, 1849 and was found a few days later.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4.
First is B as it gives the introduction of the person being talked about.
Next is A as it speaks about an incident that was the cause of great speculation
After that is D as it describes how he had gone missing
Lastly, C explains how he was found and then he died.
The correct sequence is BADC.

Question:
Identify the best way to improve the underlined part of the given sentence. If there is no improvement required, select ‘no improvement’.
I couldn’t visit my aunt as there were the traffic jam due to an accident.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2.
Were is used with plural nouns whereas was is used with singular nouns.
Also, are is used with plural nouns.
Here, traffic jam is singular so option 2 is correct.

Question:
Identify the best way to improve the underlined part of the given sentence. If there is no improvement required, select ‘no improvement’.
The metro service is so good that one doesn’t have to wait since a few minutes.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4.
The sentence wants to highlight that the metro service is so good that no one has to wait for more than a few minutes.
Since is used in the intervening period between (the time mentioned) and the time under consideration, typically the present.
For is used to indicate a purpose.
Up to means as far as.
Beyond means more than.
So, option 4 is correct.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the voice (active / passive) form of the given sentence.
They sealed all unauthorized farms on the highway.
OP1: They are sealing all unauthorized farms on the highway.
OP2: All unauthorized farms on the highway were sealed.
OP3: The authorities were sealing all unauthorized farms on the highway.
OP4: All unauthorized farms on the highway have sealed the authorities.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2.
In the passive form, the subject and the object get interchanged. So, all unauthorized farms will become a subject.
The given sentence is in the simple past tense, so the passive form will use were + past participle form of verb i.e sealed.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the narration (direct / indirect) of the given sentence.
Her mother said, “We must have a party to celebrate your promotion.”
OP1: Her mother says that they should plan a party to celebrate her promotion.
OP2: Her mother said she had been planning a party for celebrating her promotion.
OP3: Her mother said that they must have a party to celebrate her promotion.
OP4: Her mother told that they would be having a party to celebrate her promotion.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3.
The given sentence contains must which will remain unchanged in indirect form.
But, we and your will be changed to the third person form i.e they and her respectively. So, option 3 is correct.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the narration (direct / indirect) of the given sentence.
He asked me if I would like to take that apartment on rent from the next day.
OP1: “Would you have taken this apartment on rent from the next day?” he said to me.
OP2: “Would you be liking to take this apartment on rent from tomorrow?” he said to me.
OP3: “Would you like to take this apartment on rent from tomorrow?” he said to me.
OP4: “Would you had taken this apartment on rent from tomorrow?” he said to me.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3.
In the direct narration, the next day is written as tomorrow.
So, option 1 and 2 are incorrect.
The speaker is asking something, so the use of had is incorrect. So, option 3 is correct.

Question:
Given below are four jumbled sentences. Pick the option that gives their correct order.
A Unfortunately this resulted in his going to jail.
B As a child he always landed in trouble.
C Louis Armstrong was a famous jazz musician.
D Once he found a pistol and fired it in the street.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2.
First is C as it gives an introduction about the person being talked about.
Next is B as it tells us what happened as a child
After that is D as it gives details about the incident which landed him in trouble.
Last is A as it gives the result of his actions
So, the correct sequence is CBDA.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the narration (direct / indirect) of the given sentence.
My grandfather wished that God should give me success in my new venture. He further said that his prayers would always be with me.
OP1: My grandfather wished to me, “May God give to you success in your new venture! My prayers are always with you.
OP2: My grandfather says to me, “God might give you success in your new venture! My prayers are always going to be with you.”
OP3: My grandfather said to me, “Maybe God will give you success in your new venture! My prayers would always be with you.”
OP4: My grandfather said to me, “May God give you success in your new venture! My prayers will always be with you.”
Solution:
The correct answer is: My grandfather said to me, “May God give you success in your new venture! My prayers will always be with you.”
Key Points
  • When we convert indirect speech to direct speech, we need to change the verb tense, pronouns, and other expressions to reflect the original speaker's words. In this case, the original sentence is in indirect speech, and we need to change it to direct speech.
  • Option 1 is not correct because "My prayers are always with you" is not an exact reflection of the original indirect speech. Also, the use of 'to' after 'give' is superfluous in this context.
  • Option 2 is not correct because it changes the past tense of the original indirect speech to the present tense. Additionally, it uses the word "might" instead of "should," which changes the meaning of the sentence.
  • Option 3 is not correct because it changes the verb tense and uses the word "maybe," which changes the meaning of the sentence.
  • Option 4 is the correct answer because it reflects the original indirect speech accurately in direct speech. It uses the imperative mood "May God give you success" to reflect the original sentence's wish. Also, 'would always be' should be changed into 'will always be' to make the correct conversion from the indirect speech to direct speech.
Therefore, the correct answer is: My grandfather said to me, “May God give you success in your new venture! My prayers will always be with you.”

Question:
Identify the best way to improve the underlined part of the given sentence. If there is no improvement required, select ‘no improvement’.
Whenever we go out we spend a lot money on food.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4.
The preposition of should be used after a lot in order to establish a link between the quantity i.e. a lot and the money. So, option 4 is correct.
Much is used with uncountable nouns.
After most of, we require the to make it grammatically correct.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the narration (direct / indirect) of the given sentence.
The commander ordered his battalion to march on.
OP1: The commander says to his battalion, "Please march on."
OP2: The commander gives his battalion order, “March on!”
OP3: The commander says to his battalion, “March on!”
OP4: “March on!” the commander ordered his battalion.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4.
The commander is ordering, so option 1 is incorrect as it uses, please.
Also, option 2 and 3 are incorrect forms of direct speech.
The most appropriate answer is option 4.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the narration (direct / indirect) of the given sentence.
Mother said, “Sonam, don’t throw tantrums.”
OP1: Mother warns Sonam not to throw tantrums.
OP2: Mother told Sonam not to throw tantrums.
OP3: Mother says to Sonam not to throw tantrums.
OP4: Mother said that Sonam is not to throw tantrums.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2.
Key Points
The mother is using a commanding tone.
  • Said to will change into told upon conversion. So told is most appropriate.
  • The sentence is in the simple present tense. So, option 2 is correct.
Additional Information
Throw tantrums is an idiom which means "To have an outburst of childish or unreasonable anger, frustration, or ill temper."

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the voice (active / passive) form of the given sentence.
Nobody told me Vanita was unwell.
OP1: Nobody tells me that Vanita was unwell.
OP2: I wasn’t told by anybody that Vanita was unwell.
OP3: I wasn’t being told by anybody that Vanita was unwell.
OP4: Nobody told me Vanita was being unwell.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2.
In the passive form, the subject and the object get interchanged. The subject will be 'me'. But the sentence cannot begin with 'me', so it will be converted to the first person form i.e. I. The past participle form of verb will be used as the sentence is in simple past tense. 'Being' is used when the sentence is in continuous tense. So, option 2 is correct.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the narration (direct / indirect) of the given sentence.
Rita said, “I’m not feeling well.”
OP1: Rita says that I’m not feeling well
OP2: Rita said that she was not feeling well.
OP3: Rita said she will not be feeling well.
OP4: Rita said she is not feeling well.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2.
The given sentence is present continuous tense. So, the indirect narration will be past continuous tense i.e was feeling will be used. So, option 2 is correct.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the narration (direct / indirect) of the given sentence.
Kiran said, “I will reach Patna tomorrow morning.”
OP1: Kiran said that she will reach Patna tomorrow morning.
OP2: Kiran said that I will reach Patna the next morning.
OP3: Kiran said that she would reach Patna the next morning.
OP4: Kiran says that she will reach Patna tomorrow morning.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3.
The sentence contains 'will' which will change to 'would' in indirect speech. The first person will change to the second person and tomorrow will be written as next morning. So, option 3 is correct.

Question:
In the following question, out of the four alternatives, select the alternative which is the best substitute for the phrase.
Something causing shock or dismay
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4 i.e. Appalling
Key Points
  • Meaning of the words given in the option are:
    • Mischievous means causing or showing a fondness for causing trouble in a playful way.
    • Remarkable means worthy of attention; striking.
    • Frivolous means not having any serious purpose or value.
    • Appalling means something causing shock or dismay.
      For eg; She suffered appalling injuries in the accident.
  • Thus, appalling is the answer.
Additional Information
  • Some words related to fear, horror, etc.
    • ​Consternation: a feeling of anxiety or dismay, typically at something unexpected.
    • Trepidation: a feeling of fear or anxiety about something that may happen.
    • Quaking: (of a person) shake or shudder with fear.

Question:
Identify the best way to improve the underlined part of the given sentence. If there is no improvement required, select ‘no improvement’.
These houses which were built 20 years ago are now in need of repairs.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4.
'Was' is used with singular nouns whereas 'were' is used with plural nouns. Here, houses is plural. 'Who' is used while referring to a person whereas 'which' is used to refer to things. Also, we will use the past tense form of the verb i.e. built. So, option 4 is correct.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the voice (active / passive) form of the given sentence.
The play on environment issues was performed with great professionalism by our students.
OP1: The play on environment issues was being performed with great professionalism by our students.
OP2: Our students were to perform with great professionalism the play on environment issue.
OP3: Our students have been performing the play on environment issues with great professionalism.
OP4: Our students performed the play on environment issues with great professionalism.
Solution:
The correct answer is Option 4)
Explanation:
We need to follow these instructions while changing the voice of an assertive sentence.
  • Identify the subject and object of the given sentence and interchange their places.
    • 'Our students' which is an object in passive voice becomes the subject in the active voice and 'the play on environmental issues' which is the subject in passive voice becomes the object in the active voice.
  • The preposition ‘by’ before the agent used in passive is not used in the active voice.
  • 'was + V3' in passive voice becomes 'V2' in active voice.
  • Lastly, line up the remaining part.
Following these steps, we finally get-"Our students performed the play on environment issues with great professionalism."

Question:
Given below are four jumbled sentences. Pick the option that gives their correct order.
A. One of the crocodiles was four feet long and almost six years old.
B. Post this announcement a video of a crocodile attacking a dog has gone viral causing people to panic further.
C. The authorities have announced that more crocodiles would be sighted once the waters recede.
D. After the monsoon deluge the Forest Department of Vadodara has so far rescued three crocodiles which had swum into residential areas.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3.
First is D as it describes the subject that is being further talked about i.e. the three crocodiles being rescued. Next is A as it describes one of the crocodiles mentioned in D. After that is C as as B refers the announcement mentioned in C.
So, the correct sequence is DACB.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the voice (active / passive) form of the given sentence.
Teenagers don’t like being told what to do.
OP1: Teenagers should not be told what to do.
OP2: Being told what to do is not liked by teenagers.
OP3: Teenagers are not liking being told what to do.
OP4: Being told what to do was not being liked by teenagers.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2.
In the passive sentence, the subject and the object get interchanged. The subject will become 'being told'. The given sentence is in simple present tense, so the passive sentence will be of the form 'passive subject+is/are+past participle form of verb+passive object'. So, option 2 is correct.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the narration (direct / indirect) of the given sentence.
“Don’t overspeed at night,” I said to Irina.
OP1: I had been warning Irina not to overspeed at night.
OP2: I warn to Irina not to overspeed at night.
OP3: I warned Irina not to overspeed at night.
OP4: Over speeding at night is not good, I said to Irina.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3.
In the indirect speech, the past participle form of the verb and the sentence is clearly a warning so 'warned' will be used. Don't will be changed to not to. So, option 3 is correct.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the narration (direct / indirect) of the given sentence.
“You speak such good English!” said Mary.
OP1: Mary told me I was speaking much good English.
OP2: Mary exclaimed that I speak so much good English.
OP3: Mary exclaimed that I spoke very good English.
OP4: Mary exclaimed that I was speaking very good English.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3.
The sentence is clearly an exclamation. So, it should be exclaimed. The sentence is in simple present tense so we will use the past participle form of verb i.e. spoke. So, option 3 is correct.

Question:
Find a word that is the synonym of
impoverished.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3.
Impoverished means made poor.
For eg; I visited the impoverished villages.
Wealthy means having a great deal of money, resources, or assets; rich.
Spendthrift means a person who spends money in an extravagant, irresponsible way.
Penniless means having no money; very poor.
For eg; The student was penniless and couldn't afford education.
Generous means showing a readiness to give more of something, especially money, than is strictly necessary or expected.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the narration (direct / indirect) of the given sentence.
“Let’s go out for dinner. I’ve been home this whole week,” said Anna.
OP1: Anna suggested that we go out for dinner as she had been home that whole week.
OP2: Anna said to me that we must go out for dinner as she has been home that whole week.
OP3: Anna told me she was wanting to go out for dinner and had been home this whole week.
OP4: Anna told me she is at home the whole week and would like to go out for dinner.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 1.
The first part is clearly a suggestion given by Anna. In the indirect speech, the past participle form will be used. 'Have' changes to had, this changes to that and I changes to she. So, option 1 is correct.

Question:
Given below are four jumbled sentences. Pick the option that gives their correct order.
A. The most helpful thing you can do is to hold someone’s hand when they most need it.
B. Also, jotting down notes for your seniors on ward rounds is probably not the most important thing.
C. My first year as a doctor in U.K. is over and this is what I have learnt.
D. No matter what anyone tells you, writing that urgent discharge summary is not the most important thing you will do today.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4.
First is C as it gives an introduction and tells what he has learnt in one year. Next is D as it gives the first point and A and B seem to be in continuation. After that is B as it starts with 'also' and is is related to writing. Last is A.
The correct sequence is CDBA.

Question:
Given below are four jumbled sentences. Pick the option that gives their correct order.
A But a sprig was taken and planted in one of the hills of Sri Lanka.
B The original tree is no longer there.
C That sprig grew into a tree and is called Maha Bodhi tree.
D Gautam Buddha attained enlightenment under a peepal tree in Bodhgaya in Bihar.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4.
First is D as it gives the introduction as to what is being talked about in the following statements. Next is B as it refers the tree mentioned in D. After that is A as C gives the conclusion that the sprig grew into a tree.
The correct sequence is DBAC.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the voice (active / passive) form of the given sentence.
The team manager is examining the documents of all the players.
OP1: The team manager has been examining the documents of all the players.
OP2: The documents of all the players are being examined by the team manager.
OP3: The documents of all the players the team manager is examining.
OP4: Examination of the documents of all the players was done by the team manager.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2.
The given sentence is in present continuous tense. So, the passive voice will be of the form ''passive subject+is/are being + past participle form of verb + passive object''. The passive subject will be the documents. So, option 2 is correct.

Question:
Identify the segment in the sentence, which contains the grammatical error.
What shall we do on ourselves this evening?
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3.
The use of preposition 'on' is incorrect. On is used when physically in contact with and supported by (a surface) or mentioning a target or focus. So, here 'on' should not be used.
A better option would be "for" or "to".
So, the correct sentence would be "What shall we do for/to ourselves this evening?"

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the voice (active / passive) form of the given sentence.
Do not take the coastal roads during monsoons.
OP1: Coastal roads should not be taken during monsoons.
OP2: Coastal road is not being taken during monsoons.
OP3: You are not taking the coastal road during monsoons.
OP4: You will not take the coastal road during monsoons.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 1.
In the passive voice, the subject and the object get interchanged. So, 'coastal roads' will become the subject. The given sentence is an order in simple present tense. So, the passive voice will be of the form ''passive subject+should+past participle form of verb+passive object''. So, option 1 is correct.

Question:
Identify the best way to improve the underlined part of the given sentence. If there is no improvement required, select ‘no improvement’.
My student, a doctor by profession, preferring to walk to the hospital everyday.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3.
The given sentence is in simple present tense and is in third person singular form. So, we will use the third person singular form of the verb i.e. prefers. So, option 3 is correct.

Question:
Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank.
The car cleaner expressed his inability to continue cleaning my car from 1st July due to his ______ .
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4.
Disorder means an illness that disrupts normal physical or mental functions.
The most appropriate answer is 'ill-health' as it means poor physical condition and the car cleaner is just pointing out towards a general inability and not a specific disease or disorder.

Question:
Select the most appropriate option to fill in the blank.
The sky is quite overcast. We’re ______ to have rain today.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4.
Mostly means usually; generally.
Probably means almost certainly; as far as one knows or can tell.
Surely means without doubt; certainly.
Likely means such as well might happen or be true.
The speaker is making a prediction after watching the sky. So, the most appropriate word is 'likely'.

Question:
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow.
According to a new American study headed by Dr. Willis, it has been found that people who exercise in the morning seem to lose more weight than people completing the same workouts later in the day.
These findings help shed light on the vexing issue of why some people shed considerable weight with exercise and others almost none. The study adds to the growing body of science suggesting that the timing of various activities, including exercise, could affect how those activities affect us.
The relationship between exercise and body weight is somewhat befuddling. Multiple past studies show that a majority of people who take up exercise to lose weight drop fewer pounds than would be expected, given how many calories they are burning during their workouts. Some gain weight. But a few respond quite well, shedding pound after pound with the same exercise regimen that prompts others to add inches.
The Midwest Trial 2, was conducted in the University of Kansas, U.S. on how regular, supervised exercise influences body weight. The trial involved 100 overweight, previously inactive young men and women who were made to work out five times a week at a physiology lab, jogging or otherwise sweating until they had burned up to 600 calories per session.
After 10 months of this regimen, almost everyone had dropped pounds. But the extent of their losses fluctuated wildly, even though everyone was doing the same, supervised workout. A team of researchers started brainstorming what could be responsible for the enormous variability in the weight loss.
They hit upon activity timing. They decided to do a Follow -up study of the Mid West Trial 2. In this new study, the Mid West Trial 2 Follow up study the researchers now studied a team of participants who could visit the gym whenever they wished between 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. They also tracked everyone’s calorie intakes and daily movement habits throughout the 10 months. They knew, too, whether and by how much people’s weights had changed. Now, they checked weight change against exercise schedules and quickly noticed a consistent pattern.
Those people who usually worked out before noon had lost more weight, on average, than the men and women who typically exercised after 3 p.m. The researchers uncovered a few other, possibly relevant differences between the morning and late-day exercisers. The early-exercise group tended to be slightly more active throughout the day, taking more steps in total than those who worked out later. They also ate less.
These factors may cumulatively have contributed to the striking differences in how many pounds people lost, Dr. Willis says.
Thus it seems that people who worked out before noon lost more weight, on average, than those who typically exercised after 3 p.m.
But Dr. Willis also points out that most of those who worked out later in the day did lose weight, even if not as much as the larkish exercisers, and almost certainly became healthier. “I would not want anyone to think that it’s not worth exercising if you can’t do it first thing in the morning,” he says. “Any exercise, at any time of day, is going to be better than none.”

Question:
The Mid West Trail 2 was a
OP1: U.S based study on 100 participants who exercised 3 times a week and burnt 300 calories.
OP2: Canadian study on 500 participants who exercised 6 times a week and burnt 600 calories.
OP3: A European study on 100 participants who exercised 7 times a week and burnt 800 calories.
OP4: U.S based study on 100 participants who exercised 5 times a week and burnt 600 calories
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4.
It is mentioned that ''The Midwest Trial 2, was conducted in the University of Kansas, U.S. on how regular, supervised exercise influences body weight. The trial involved 100 overweight, previously inactive young men and women who were made to work out five times a week at a physiology lab, jogging or otherwise sweating until they had burned up to 600 calories per session.'' So, option 4 is correct.

The trial involved 100 overweight, previously inactive young men and women who were made to work out five times a week at a physiology lab, jogging or otherwise sweating until they had burned up to 600 calories per session.
After 10 months of this regimen, almost everyone had dropped pounds. But the extent of their losses fluctuated wildly, even though everyone was doing the same, supervised workout. A team of researchers started brainstorming what could be responsible for the enormous variability in the weight loss.
They hit upon activity timing. They decided to do a Follow -up study of the Mid West Trial 2. In this new study, the Mid West Trial 2 Follow up study the researchers now studied a team of participants who could visit the gym whenever they wished between 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. They also tracked everyone’s calorie intakes and daily movement habits throughout the 10 months. They knew, too, whether and by how much people’s weights had changed. Now, they checked weight change against exercise schedules and quickly noticed a consistent pattern.
Those people who usually worked out before noon had lost more weight, on average, than the men and women who typically exercised after 3 p.m. The researchers uncovered a few other, possibly relevant differences between the morning and late-day exercisers. The early-exercise group tended to be slightly more active throughout the day, taking more steps in total than those who worked out later. They also ate less.
These factors may cumulatively have contributed to the striking differences in how many pounds people lost, Dr. Willis says.
Thus it seems that people who worked out before noon lost more weight, on average, than those who typically exercised after 3 p.m.
But Dr. Willis also points out that most of those who worked out later in the day did lose weight, even if not as much as the larkish exercisers, and almost certainly became healthier. “I would not want anyone to think that it’s not worth exercising if you can’t do it first thing in the morning,” he says. “Any exercise, at any time of day, is going to be better than none.”

Question:
Identify the best way to improve the underlined part of the given sentence. If there is no improvement required, select ‘no improvement’.
I am going to see a play tomorrow evening.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4.
The sentence describes an action that is going to occur in future.
So, we will use the basic form of the verb along with 'am going' in the present continuous form i.e. see. So, option 4 is correct.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the narration (direct / indirect) of the given sentence.
Reena said, “What a lovely scene! I wish I could stay here forever!”
OP1: Reena says this is a lovely scene. I wish I could stay there forever.
OP2: Reena said with happiness that was a lovely scene. She wishes to stay there forever.
OP3: Reena said what a lovely scene! She wished she could stay here forever.
OP4: Reena exclaimed that it was a lovely scene. She further wished that she could stay there forever.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4.
The sentence is clearly an exclamation. So, we will use exclaimed. The indirect form will use 'she' instead of 'I' and use the past participle form of the verbs. In the second part, wished should be used as the act of wishing is taking place in the present.
When we convert a sentence from direct to indirect speech, we make the following changes:
  • Quotation marks are omitted and the sentence ends with a full stop.
  • The tense of the verb, in the reported speech involving any order, request and instruction does not undergo any change during the conversion from direct to indirect mode. This is also true if the statement is a universal truth.
  • If the reporting verb is in the present tense, it does not undergo any change.
  • We add the word 'to' before the verb if the verb is in bare infinitive.
  • When the reporting or principal verb is in the present tense, all present tenses of the direct are changed into the corresponding past tenses.
  • Words expressing nearness in time or place are generally converted into into words expressing distance. For eg. now becomes then, today becomes that day, yesterday becomes the previous day, this becomes that etc.
  • In reporting commands and requests, the verb expressing command or request is added and the imperative is changed into the infinitive.
  • In reporting questions the verbs like asked, inquired are added
  • In reporting exclamations and wishes, the verbs expressing exclamation or wish are added.
  • When we convert a sentence from the direct to the indirect mode(especially for a sentence ending with a mark of interrogation), we reverse the subject-verb placement. In direct sentences, we have the verb before the subject; while in indirect, the verb follows the subject.
So, option 4 is correct.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the voice (active / passive) form of the given sentence.
Preparations are being made for our Annual fest.
OP1: We have made preparations for our Annual fest.
OP2: Our Annual fest preparations are made.
OP3: Preparations were being made for our Annual fest.
OP4: We are making preparations for our Annual fest.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4.
The given sentence is in the passive voice and the tense is in its present continuous form.
Rules of Conversion from Passive to Active Voice:
1. Identify the subject, the verb and the object: S+V+O
2. Change the subject into object
3. Omit the helping verb or auxiliary verb according to the tense.
4. Change the past participle form of the verb into the simple past form.
5. Omit the preposition "by“
6. Change the object into subject
Example:
Active Voice: Sameer wrote a letter. (Subject) + (verb) + (object).
Passive Voice: A letter was written by Sameer. (Object) + (auxiliary verb) + (past participle) + (by subject).
Option 4 follows all the rules for sentence transformation.

Question:
Find a word that is the synonym of
Philanthropist
Solution:
The correct answer is humanist.
Key Points
Philanthropist means a person who seeks to promote the welfare of others, especially by the generous donation of money to good causes.
For eg; The trust was founded by a philanthropist.
Humanist is a person concerned with or seeking to promote human welfare.
For eg; They have a humanitarian purpose.
Additional Information
The meaning of the other words-
  • Philosopher means a person engaged or learned in philosophy, especially as an academic discipline.
  • Misanthropist means a person who dislikes humankind and avoids human society.
  • Anarchist means an a person who rebels against any authority, established order, or ruling power.

Question:

Something happening by chance in a happy and beneficial way
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4 i.e. Serendipity
Key Points
  • Meaning of the words given in the options are:
    • Fortitude means courage in pain or adversity.
    • Serenity means the state of being calm, peaceful, and untroubled.
    • Misadventure means an unfortunate incident; a mishap.
    • Serendipity means the occurrence and development of events by chance in a happy or beneficial way.
      ​For eg; It was a fortunate incident of serendipity.
  • Thus, serendipity is the correct answer.
Additional Information
  • Some other words related to happiness are:
    • ​Euphoria: Euphoria is a feeling of intense happiness and excitement.
    • Mirthful: full of, expressing, or causing mirth; merry
    • Rapturous: A rapturous feeling or reaction is one of extreme happiness or enthusiasm.
    • Vivacity: If you say that someone has vivacity, you mean that they are lively, exciting, and attractive.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the voice (active / passive) form of the given sentence.
Please give me some more time to complete the assignments.
OP1: I may please be given some more time to complete the assignments.

In the passive voice, the subject and the object get interchanged.
  • The subject will become 'I' as 'me' is the object of the given sentence.
  • So, options 2 and 4 are incorrect. Option 3 is using the present continuous form which is incorrect as the sentence is in simple past tense.
  • So, the required sentence must be of the form 'passive subject+be+ past participle form + passive object'.
  • Hence, the correct structure and the past participle verb are both present only in Option 1.
Thus Option 1 is the correct answer.

Question:

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the voice (active / passive) form of the given sentence.
We have written all the library rules on the notice-board.
OP1: All the library rules are being written on the notice-board.
OP2: All the library rules were written on the notice-board.
OP3: All the library rules have been written on the notice-board.
OP4: We are writing all the library rules on the notice-board.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3.
The given sentence is in active voice and the verb used is in the present perfect tense.
Rules of Conversion from Active to Passive Voice:
1. Identify the subject, the verb and the object: S+V+O
2. Change the object into subject
3. Put the suitable helping verb or auxiliary verb according to the tense present.
4. Change the verb into past participle of the verb
5. Add the preposition "by“
6. Change the subject into object
Example:
Active Voice: Sameer wrote a letter. (Subject) + (verb) + (object).
Passive Voice: A letter was written by Sameer. (Object) + (auxiliary verb) + (past participle) + (by subject).
Option 3 follows all the required rules of sentence transformation.

Question:

It takes me one hour to get to work in the morning in week days.

The correct answer is 'In week days'

  • 'In' is used when something is surrounded by the other.
  • 'On' can be used to indicate a time of day or a particular day. Here, 'on' should be used.
  • Therefore error lies in 'in week days' therefore it is the correct answer.
Therefore the correct statement is: 'It takes me one hour to get to work in the morning on week days'

Rules of Conversion from Passive to Active Voice:

Example:

Option 2 follows all the proper rules for sentence transformation.

Question:
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow.
A few years ago it seemed as if the moment for stand-up comedy had arrived. By the end of 2017, stand-up comedians were on the cover of a magazine, signaling the coming of age of the industry.
The stand-up game attracted investors in the right places: on platforms like Netflix and Amazon Prime, apart from increasing open mic schedules in venues across cities. Two major companies Comedy Store and Canvas Laugh Club arrived on the scene and were game changers.
But despite a heady start, the comic landscape has changed drastically today with stand- up comedians feeling the brunt of faltering payments and cancelled shows. Despite a good start, the Indian stand-up industry is still unorganized and uncertain for comics.
If you ask viral comic Kunal Kamra about the scene, he says that the audience isn’t really ‘invested’ in the art form at the moment and that only ten or twenty tickets would sell if comics weren’t on the internet promoting themselves. And this is despite the surge in open mics and more stand-ups coming in.
Last year, new-age Indian comedy’s reputation came under strain when allegations under the #MeToo movement exposed a darker side of the circuit. Since then, the big three comedy groups: All India Bakchod, SNG Comedy and East India Comedy, have either disbanded or had founding members quit.
Jeeya Sethi, a leading comedian says, “It’s a good thing that these -collectives have died because they mostly had men with no women being showcased.”
Sethi adds saying that it isn’t as easy as it sounds. “In a fledgling industry, a viral YouTube video isn’t a sign that you’ve made it”. Craft takes time. Every comic who does two open mics calls himself a comedian. In my opinion, you have to do comedy for more than 20 years to be a comic. It takes at least five years to find your voice.”

Solution:

With the given statement the author means that stand-up comedy is a new art form and it will take time to build an audience. This is because in the passage also the author says that only ten or twenty tickets would sell if comics weren’t on the internet promoting themselves.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the narration (direct / indirect) of the given sentence.
The salesman said to me, “All the gift items are new. We received this consignment yesterday.”
OP1: The salesman said to me that all the gift items are new. We received that consignment yesterday.
OP2: The salesman informed to me about all the gift items that they were new. They received that consignment the day before.
OP3: The salesman told me that all the gift items are new. He further said we received this consignment yesterday.
OP4: The salesman informed me that all the gift items were new. He further said they had received that consignment the day before.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4.
  • The first statement is the information given by the salesman to the receiver. So, 'informed' must be used.
  • The use of preposition 'to' with informed is incorrect.
  • The first sentence is in simple present tense so 'are' will be changed to 'were'.
  • Also, the second statement is giving further information and yesterday will be written as 'the day before'.
  • So, option 4 is correct.

When we convert a sentence from direct to indirect speech, we make the following changes:
  • Quotation marks are omitted and the sentence ends with a full stop.
  • The tense of the verb, in the reported speech involving any order, request and instruction does not undergo any change during the conversion from direct to indirect mode. This is also true if the statement is a universal truth.
  • If the reporting verb is in the present tense, it does not undergo any change.
  • We add the word 'to' before the verb if the verb is in bare infinitive.
  • When the reporting or principal verb is in the present tense, all present tenses of the direct are changed into the corresponding past tenses.
  • Words expressing nearness in time or place are generally converted into into words expressing distance. For eg. now becomes then, today becomes that day, yesterday becomes the previous day, this becomes that etc.
  • In reporting commands and requests, the verb expressing command or request is added and the imperative is changed into the infinitive.
  • In reporting questions the verbs like asked, inquired are added
  • In reporting exclamations and wishes, the verbs expressing exclamation or wish are added.
  • When we convert a sentence from the direct to the indirect mode(especially for a sentence ending with a mark of interrogation), we reverse the subject-verb placement. In direct sentences, we have the verb before the subject; while in indirect, the verb follows the subject.
Option 4 satisfies all the criteria and is the answer.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the narration (direct / indirect) of the given sentence.
My friend told me I could stay at his place in Dehradun whenever I wished.
OP1: My friend said, “You will come and be staying in my place in Dehradun whenever you wish.”
OP2: My friend said, “You can stay at my place in Dehradun whenever you wish.’’
OP3: My friend said, “If you are wishing to come to Dehradun come and stay in my place.”
OP4: My friend said, “You will be coming to stay at my place in Dehradun whenever you wish.”
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2.
In the direct form, could will be changed to can.
'I' will be changed to 'you'. The given sentence is in simple past tense so the direct form will be in the simple present tense.
Therefore we will use the first form of the verb. So, option 2 is correct.
When we convert a sentence from indirect to direct speech, we make the following changes:
  • Quotation marks are added and the sentence ends with a full stop, comma or interrogation mark depending on the tone of the reported speech.
  • The tense of the verb, in the reported speech involving any order, request and instruction does not undergo any change during the conversion from indirect to direct mode. This is also true if the statement is a universal truth.
  • If the reporting verb is in the present tense, it does not undergo any change.
  • We omit the word 'to' before the verb if the verb is in bare infinitive.
  • When the reporting or principal verb is in the past tense, all past tenses of the indirect are changed into the corresponding present tenses.
  • Words expressing distance are generally converted into into words expressing nearness in time or place. For eg. then becomes now, that day becomes today, that becomes this etc.
  • In reporting commands and requests, the verb expressing command or request is omitted and the infinitive is changed into the imperative.
  • In reporting questions the verbs like asked, inquired are omitted and replaced by 'said to'.
  • In reporting exclamations and wishes, the verb expressing exclamation or wish is omitted and simply replaced by 'said'

Question:
Identify the segment in the sentence, which contains the grammatical error.
He likes to put all the garbage into a black small bag.
Solution:
The correct answer is Option 4.
The error lies in the last part of the sentence.
A noun is modified by the adjective. In the sentence, the adjective is placed before the noun. The sentence is thus grammatically incorrect.
The correct sentence will be: He likes to put all the garbage into a small black bag.

Identify the best way to improve the underlined part of the given sentence. If there is no improvement required, select ‘no improvement’.
I have an invite from a friend to visit the Canada and United States next month.

OP4: to the Canada and United States
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2.
The is not used before the names of countries, states, cities, etc. So, 'the' before Canada is incorrect. But 'the' is included in the name of the United States. So, option 2 is correct. To is already used before visit so it is not required after visit.

In the given improvement it should be 'Since I saw'
The concept is: As it is the present perfect tense we have to use 'since' as it indicates the point in time and the subordinate clause i.e 'since
clause' should be written in past indefinite tense. In simple words, If an event in the past is used as a 'point in time' with 'since' it must be written in past indefinite tense.
Let's see an example:
They have spent much money since they launched this project.
So the correct sentence is:
It has been two years since I saw Meena.

Question:
Choose the most appropriate option to change the voice (active / passive) form of the given sentence.
Two children were shot dead by a psychopath during the California music festival.
OP1: Two children were being shot dead by a psychopath during the California music festival.
OP2: A psychopath shot dead two children during the California music festival.
OP3: A psychopath during the California music festival was shooting dead two children.
OP4: Two children are shot dead by a psychopath during the California music festival.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2)
Explanation:
We need to follow these instructions while changing the voice of an assertive sentence.
  • Identify the subject and object of the given sentence and interchange their places.
    • 'A psychopath' which is an object in the passive voice becomes the subject in active voice and 'Two children' which is a subject in passive voice becomes the object in active voice.
  • 'Was/Were + V3' in passive voice becomes 'V2' in active voice.
  • Use the preposition ‘by’ before the agent.
  • Lastly, line up the remaining part.
Following these steps, we finally get- "A psychopath shot dead two children during the California music festival."

Question:
Identify the segment in the sentence, which contains the grammatical error.
I had to go to the doctor because I was not bear the pain in my tooth.
Solution:
The erroneous part is: was not bear.
Key Points
  • The phrase 'I was not bear the pain' is grammatically incorrect.
  • The form we use to convey inability in English is 'cannot' or the contraction 'can't'.
  • The verb 'bear' in this context means to tolerate or endure something, like pain. So, it needs a helper verb like 'could' to correctly convey the intended meaning.
  • Since the sentence is narrating a past event (signified by 'had to go'), it's important to maintain consistency in the tenses used. Hence, the past tense form 'could' suits better than 'can' in this scenario.
Therefore, the correct answer is: I had to go to the doctor because I could not bear the pain in my tooth.

Rules of Conversion from Active to Passive Voice:
1. Identify the subject, the verb and the object: S+V+O
2. Change the object into subject
3. Put the suitable helping verb or auxiliary verb
4. Change the verb into past participle of the verb
5. Add the preposition "by“
6. Change the subject into object
Example:
Active Voice: Sameer wrote a letter. (Subject) + (verb) + (object).
Passive Voice: A letter was written by Sameer. (Object) + (auxiliary verb) + (past participle) + (by subject).

Solution:
The correct answer is option 4.

The past form of the verbs will be changed to present tense.
When we convert a sentence from indirect to direct speech, we make the following changes:
  • Quotation marks are added and the sentence ends with a full stop, comma or interrogation mark depending on the tone of the reported speech.
  • The tense of the verb, in the reported speech involving any order, request and instruction does not undergo any change during the conversion from indirect to direct mode. This is also true if the statement is a universal truth.
  • If the reporting verb is in the present tense, it does not undergo any change.
  • We omit the word 'to' before the verb if the verb is in bare infinitive.
  • When the reporting or principal verb is in the past tense, all past tenses of the indirect are changed into the corresponding present tenses.
  • Words expressing distance are generally converted into into words expressing nearness in time or place. For eg. then becomes now, that day becomes today, that becomes this etc.
  • In reporting commands and requests, the verb expressing command or request is omitted and the infinitive is changed into the imperative.
  • In reporting questions the verbs like asked, inquired are omitted and replaced by 'said to'.
  • In reporting exclamations and wishes, the verb expressing exclamation or wish is omitted and simply replaced by 'said'.

When we convert a sentence from direct to indirect speech, we make the following changes:
  • Quotation marks are omitted and the sentence ends with a full stop.
  • The tense of the verb, in the reported speech involving any order, request and instruction does not undergo any change during the conversion from direct to indirect mode. This is also true if the statement is a universal truth.
  • If the reporting verb is in the present tense, it does not undergo any change.
  • We add the word 'to' before the verb if the verb is in bare infinitive.
  • When the reporting or principal verb is in the present tense, all present tenses of the direct are changed into the corresponding past tenses.
  • Words expressing nearness in time or place are generally converted into into words expressing distance. For eg. now becomes then, today becomes that day, yesterday becomes the previous day, this becomes that etc.
  • In reporting commands and requests, the verb expressing command or request is added and the imperative is changed into the infinitive.
  • In reporting questions the verbs like asked, inquired are added
  • In reporting exclamations and wishes, the verbs expressing exclamation or wish are added.
  • When we convert a sentence from the direct to the indirect mode(especially for a sentence ending with a mark of interrogation), we reverse the subject-verb placement. In direct sentences, we have the verb before the subject; while in indirect, the verb follows the subject.

Question:

When my friend suggested going to the mall for lunch, I agreed ______ .

The correct answer is option 3.

Question:
Given below are four jumbled sentences. Pick the option that gives their correct order.
A They also believe that one must not hold on to things if one doesn’t use them and love them anymore.

D Minimalists believe that clutter causes a lot of stress and wastes precious space.

So, the correct sequence is DACB.

Question:
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow.
The United Kingdom’s Social Mobility Commission study reports that disadvantaged children in England are being priced out of a cultural hinterland. Children aged 10-15 from low-income families are three times less likely than wealthier peers to engage in out-of-school musical activities, such as learning an instrument etc.
There were also differences according to race – 4% of British Pakistani children took part in music classes, compared with 28% of Indian children and 20% of white children – and regional divides: 9% of children in north-east England played a musical instrument, compared with 22% in the south-east.
Disadvantaged children are also more likely to miss out on extracurricular sports (football, boxing, cricket) and drama, dance and art. The commission set out recommendations, including bursaries, better funding and support for schools – let’s hope they’re taken on board. As well as the activities themselves, children are missing out on other crucial gains including confidence-building, team spirit and social skill, and are less likely to go on to higher education.
Extracurricular activities tend to cost money, but there are also problems with a lack of availability and access, such as schools being unable to afford to run after-school clubs or stay open during holidays. Another barrier is the kids’ “fear of not fitting in”. In this sense, certain children are self-excluding from, say, learning an instrument, singing in a choir, playing cricket or acting. They decide by themselves that they’re “undeserving” of music, sport, art and drama. Unbelievably, in 2019, children as young as 10 are already hard-wired with the self-limiting poverty notion of “not for the likes of us”.
This is heartbreaking. It’s hardly news that life is tougher for poorer children, but it’s an outrage if all sense of curiosity, artistry, and playfulness is knocked out of them so early. Something is wrong if better-off children feel entitled to explore and participate in areas that interest and excite them, while the disadvantaged are cast from the start as cultural wallflowers – doomed to sit out every dance.
This isn’t about every child learning the piano or violin (but why not?), it’s about sowing the seeds for a cultural hinterland that will sustain and enrich them for life. It’s about people exploring their passions and refusing to have their horizons artificially limited. Regardless of circumstances, all children should know that their faces “fit” – automatically and forever. Culture belongs to everyone.

Question:
The probability of a child in United Kingdom getting opportunities to engage in cultural and sports activities depends on-
1. parental economic background
2. whether one parent is British
3. whether parents have a university education
4. kind of school and funding available Of the above points which are correct
Solution:
The correct answer is option 2.
It is mentioned that ''Disadvantaged children are also more likely to miss out on extracurricular sports (football, boxing, cricket) and drama, dance and art. Extracurricular activities tend to cost money, but there are also problems with a lack of availability and access, such as schools being unable to afford to run after-school clubs or stay open during holidays.'' Therefore, the probability depends on the parental economic background and kind of school and funding available Of the above points which are correct.

Question:
Identify the segment in the sentence, which contains the grammatical error.
High level security arrangements were made for the forthcoming visit to a Japanese Prime Minister.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 3.
'To' is used to express a location or the result of a process.
Here, the use of 'to' is incorrect as the sentence talks about the arrival of the Prime minister.
Instead of 'to', 'of' must be used as it expresses the relation between the other part of the sentence with the Japanese Prime Minister.
Moreover, 'the' should be used before 'Japanese Prime Minister' as in the sentence we are referring specifically to the Prime Minister of Japan.

Predecessor.
